case_title: M/s. Muhammad Yousuf Adil vs Deputy Commissioner SRB, Karachi

accussed_details.name: M/s. Muhammad Yousuf Adil
allegation: Failure to register for Sindh Sales Tax on Services
Providing taxable services (renting of immovable property)

complaint_summary: The appellant allegedly provided taxable services (renting of immovable property) since July 2015 without registering with SRB, violating the Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011.
investigation_summary: The appellant was issued a show-cause notice on 20.05.2016 under Section 24B of the Act. An ex-parte order was passed on 31.05.2016 imposing compulsory registration and a penalty of Rs. 100,000 if voluntary registration was not completed by 15.06.2016.
judgment_summary: The appeal was allowed based on the Sindh High Court judgment in CP No.D-2421/2016, which held that mere renting of immovable property does not constitute a taxable service under the Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011. Both the order-in-original and order-in-appeal were set aside.
legal_arguments: The renting of immovable property does not involve taxable services as defined under the Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011.
The Sindh High Court judgment in CP No.D-2421/2016 clarified that rent received by landlords cannot be subjected to tax unless it involves economic activity or provision of services.
statutes: Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011
citations: Youngs (Private Limited versus Province of Sindh and others)
key_issues: Whether renting of immovable property constitutes a taxable service under the Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011.
Validity of compulsory registration and penalty imposed by SRB.

legal_terms.Taxable Service: A service subject to tax under the relevant statute.
legal_terms.Economic Activity: An activity involving the provision of services in the course of business or commerce.

words_and_phrases.Renting of Immovable Property: Letting out property for consideration without involving taxable services.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the interpretation of taxable services under the Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011. The appellant challenged the compulsory registration and penalty imposed by SRB for renting immovable property. The Sindh High Court judgment clarified that mere renting does not constitute a taxable service unless it involves economic activity or provision of services. The appeal was allowed, and prior orders were set aside.

facts.act: Sindh Sales Tax on Services Act, 2011
facts.allegation: Appellant provided taxable services since July 2015 but failed to register with SRB.

order_in_original.penalty: Rs. 100,000 if not voluntarily registered by 2016-06-15

key_judgment_points.precedent_case: Youngs (Private Limited) vs Province of Sindh
key_findings: Renting of immovable property does not involve provision of taxable services.
Economic activity must involve provision of services to be taxable under the Act.
Provincial legislature cannot impose tax on rent received by landlords.
